metadata.case_name: West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd. v. State of Madras

facts.text: The appellant, West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd., Rajapalayam, was incorporated in 1935 to carry on the business of an electric light and power company, to construct, lay down and establish and carry on all necessary installations, to generate, accumulate, distribute and supply electricity under a licence granted under the Indian Electricity Act of 1910.

On 24th January 1950, the Madras Legislature passed Madras Act XLIII of 1949 for the acquisition of undertakings supplying electricity in the Province of Madras. Under s.4(1) of the said Act, the respondent, State of Madras, passed Order G.O. Ms. No.2059 on 17th May 1951, declaring that the appellant undertaking shall vest in the respondent from 21st September 1951.

Thereafter, the respondent appointed the Chief Electrical Inspector as the Acquisition Officer, and on the appointed day (21st September 1951), the said Officer took over possession of the appellant and all its assets, records and account-books.

The appellant appointed the liquidator as its Accredited Representative for the purposes of the Act to claim compensation. The respondent paid Rs. 6 lakhs on 24th October 1952 and Rs. 2,34,387-1-0 on 5th July 1953 as compensation. Appellant claims Rs. 98,876-15-0 still due; respondent says Rs. 6000.

Owners of some electrical undertakings filed writ petitions in Madras High Court impugning 1949 Act; failed except for municipalities. Upheld in Narasaraopeta Electric Corporation Ltd. v. State of Madras (1951) 11 M.L.J. 277.

Appeals to Supreme Court succeeded; in Rajamundry Electric Supply Corporation Ltd. v. State of Andhra (1954) S.C.R. 779, held 1949 Act ultra vires as beyond legislative competence under Government of India Act 1935.
Constitution came into force 26th January 1950. Entries 36 List II and 42 List III Seventh Schedule enable acquisition.

After Rajamundry decision, Madras Legislature passed Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings Acquisition Act 1954 (XXIX of 1954), assented by President 9th October 1954, published 13th October 1954. Incorporated main provisions of 1949 Act and validated actions under it.
Respondent issued new G.O. No. 4388 on 14th December 1954 appointing Chief Electrical Inspector as Acquisition Officer for appellant.

Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 326 of 1955 on 26th April 1955 challenging Act's validation of 1949 Act actions and compensation bases inconsistent with Art. 31; prayed quashing G.O. Ms. No. 2059 of 17th May 1951.
Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 107 of 1956 on 31st January 1956 adding prayer for mandamus to restore possession with mesne profits from 21st September 1951 or market value plus 6% interest.
Madras High Court (Rajagopalan J.) dismissed petitions on 27th March 1956; held even if s.24 invalid, no relief as compensation accepted; Act and s.24 valid; compensation not shown inadequate.
Certificate under Art. 132 granted; appeals to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Validity of s.24 of the Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings Acquisition Act, 1954, which purports to validate actions taken under the earlier invalid 1949 Act.
Whether the impugned notification of 17th May 1951 (vesting from 21st Sep 1951) is validated by s.24, assuming it is a 'law' under Art.13.
Whether the notification contravenes Art.31(1) as no antecedent law, and if retrospective validation cures it.
Whether legislature can pass retrospective law to validate actions under void law that contravened fundamental rights.
Whether s.5 of 1954 Act provides compensation consistent with Art.31(2) (pre-4th Amendment).

petitioner_arguments.text: S.24 is ineffective to validate 17th May 1951 order as Act is prospective; no express retrospective provision.
Notification invalid under void 1949 Act (beyond competence) and post-Constitution offends Art.31(1); s.24 cannot retrospectively validate as no antecedent law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.31(1); Deep Chand v. State of U.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: Legislature cannot retrospectively cure contravention of fundamental rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Deep Chand v. State of U.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.5 compensation bases (A,B,C) inadequate, not just equivalent; e.g., no market value, ignores rises; contrast s.7A Electricity Act 1910.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.31(2); State of W.B. v. Bela Banerjee; s.7A Indian Electricity Act 1910

respondent_arguments.text: Act valid; s.24 retrospectively validates actions under 1949 Act; possession deemed under 1954 Act; no relief for possession/mesne profits in writ as compensation accepted.
No material to show s.5 compensation inadequate.

court_reasoning.text: Act's scheme (definitions ss.2(b),(j),(e),(m); ss.3,4,7,10,11,14) applies to pre-existing taken-over undertakings; material provisions retrospective; s.24 validates notifications properly issued under 1949 Act (assuming valid) unless repugnant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.24 saving/validating provision effectively deems actions under 1954 Act.

court_reasoning.text: Notification validated by retrospective s.24; Art.31(1) satisfied as retrospective operation means provisions existed at time; unlike Art.20(1) 'law in force'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrospective law provides 'authority of law' under Art.31(1).

court_reasoning.text: Legislature competent to retrospectively validate void actions whether for lack of competence or FR violation; same result (void ab initio); power includes retrospective laws on List topics.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No limitation on retrospective power even for FR; precedents affirm (e.g. Income Tax amendments, Sales Tax Validation Act).

court_reasoning.text: S.5 bases (A:20x avg profit; B:share values; C:book values + solatium) prima facie provide just equivalent for going concerns; no material (affidavits) to show inadequacy; licensee chooses basis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absence of material; scheme not patently inadequate like Bela Banerjee ceiling.

holdings.text: S.24 validly and effectively validates actions under 1949 Act including impugned notification.
Retrospective validation satisfies Art.31(1); legislature can retrospectively validate void actions even involving FR contravention.
S.5 provides compensation per Art.31(2) as no material shows otherwise.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the validity of the Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings Acquisition Act, 1954, including s.24's retrospective validation of actions under the invalid 1949 Act, and s.5's compensation provisions as consistent with Art.31(2) due to lack of material showing inadequacy. Writ petitions dismissed by High Court affirmed; no relief for possession or mesne profits needed.

key_quotes.text: The Act, in terms, is intended to apply to undertakings of which possession had already been taken, and that obviously means that its material and operative provisions are retrospective.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If a law is invalid for the reason that it has been passed by a legislature without legislative competence... the said action can be validated by a subsequent law... the same power cannot be equally effectively exercised... in validating actions taken under law which are void for the reason that they contravened fundamental rights.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds legislature can retrospectively validate FR-violating void laws.

key_quotes.text: In the absence of any material, we do not see how we can assess the validity of... contention that section 5 contravenes Art.31(2) of the Constitution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects compensation challenge for lack of evidence.
